result.execSummary:
The defendant Andrew R Kaminski was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Huber granted if approved by the jail administration. - stayed

miscConds.notes: Pay costs and DNA surcharge. If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.

Maintain absolute sobriety. 
Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment.
Complete a parenting class or if recently completed, may provide proof to satisfy the requirement.
Engage in any other counseling as recommended by the agent.
Submit to DNA sample.
AODA assessment or provide proof of recent assessment to agent to satisfy the recommendation, comply with all treatment recommendations from assessment.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

records.addlTxt: Portage County DNA Proof of Submission

Defendant Andrew R Kaminski in court with attorney Acalia Halverson. Elizabeth R. Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  

11:16 AM Court calls case.
Court states appearances.

Defendant will plead to single count in complaint.
There is a plea agreement.

Atty Halverson concurs with agreement.

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.

Defendant enters a plea of: NO CONTEST

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney Halverson for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge.

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge.
Court finds the defendant guilty.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.
Count 1: Contrary to the statute section stated therein

State has complied with victim notification statutes.
Victim is not present.

Atty Constable makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Atty Halverson makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Defendant addresses the Court prior to sentencing.

Court has a number of factors to consider to determine sentencing.

BY THE COURT:
Count 1:
Jail sentence for 90 days, Imposed and Stayed
Huber granted if approved by the jail administration
Probation for a period of 12 Months
Conditions:
AODA assessment or provide proof of recent assessment to agent to satisfy the recommendation, comply with all treatment recommendations from assessment
Maintain absolute sobriety 
Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment
Complete a parenting class or if recently completed, may provide proof to satisfy the requirement
Engage in any other counseling as recommended by the agent
Submit to DNA sample
Pay costs
Pay DNA surcharge

Appeal rights addressed.
